title: Arrival of the Mayflower
description: The Mayflower arrived at Cape Cod in November 1620, bringing the first Pilgrims to New England.

title: Declaration of Independence
description: The Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Continental Congress on July 4, 1776.

title: Louisiana Purchase
description: The United States purchased the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803, doubling the size of the nation.

title: Emancipation Proclamation
description: President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863, declaring all slaves in Confederate territory free.

title: Completion of the Transcontinental Railroad
description: The First Transcontinental Railroad was completed in 1869, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific coasts.

title: Women's Suffrage
description: The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, granting women the right to vote, was ratified on August 18, 1920.

title: Great Depression
description: The Great Depression was the worst economic downturn in the history of the industrialized world, lasting from 1929 to 1939.

title: Attack on Pearl Harbor
description: The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, led the United States to enter World War II.

title: D-Day Invasion
description: On June 6, 1944, Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy, France, in the largest seaborne invasion in history.

title: Civil Rights Act of 1964
description: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was signed into law, prohibiting discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.

title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
description: Apollo 11 was the first manned mission to land on the Moon, on July 20, 1969.

title: Watergate Scandal
description: The Watergate scandal led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon on August 8, 1974.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, leading to the reunification of Germany and the end of the Cold War.

title: September 11 Attacks
description: Terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001, resulted in the destruction of the World Trade Center and significant loss of life.

title: First African-American President
description: Barack Obama was inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States on January 20, 2009, becoming the first African-American president.
